Meeting of the Synod

Of the Diocese of Saskatchewan.

The second Session of the Synod of the Diocese of Saskatchewan, met at Prince Albert, on Friday, Nov. 13th, at St. Mary's Church.

There came clergy and laity by delegates from the various parishes.

The proceedings were characterized by harmony and good feeling throughout.

His Lordship, the Bishop of Saskatchewan, declared that he was pleased to meet his people in an atmosphere of peace and prosperity.

My Resolutions have been approved.

Since we met last year important changes have been made in our Diocese and Province. All the churches now belong to the Diocese of Saskatchewan. The new Diocesan Board has been set up. They are to be commended as they continue to work tirelessly for the interests of all within their jurisdiction.

The next item of business was the election of delegates to the Provincial Council. It was agreed that they would be elected by the Presbyteries.

Another major change made by the Provincial Council was the establishment of a new Diocese in the northern part of the province.

The Bishop, who presided over the service, indicated that he was pleased with the progress made by the Diocese since its formation.

He called upon all members of the Diocese to continue to support the work of the Church in this challenging time.

He stressed the importance of working together as a united force in order to achieve our goals.

The meeting closed with prayers and hymns.

Meeting of the Synod of the Diocese of Saskatchewan

The meeting of the Synod of the Diocese of Saskatchewan was held in Prince Albert on October 17th. The Bishop of the Diocese, Rev. Dr. James Suter, presided over the proceedings. After opening prayers, the Bishop delivered an address to the members of the Synod. He reminded them of their responsibilities as members of the Church and encouraged them to continue their work in the diocese.

At the conclusion of the address, the Bishop announced that he would be visiting England soon. He expressed his hope that the members of the Synod would continue their work in the diocese during his absence.

The meeting adjourned at noon.

Copy of a Memorandum to the Governor-General by the North-West Committee.

To His Excellency,

The Government of Canada:

May it please your Excellency:

Your Memorandum the Lieutenant-Governor and the North-West Committee respectfully submit the following:

1. That the representations held by the Government in regard to the clause in the Land Act which provides for the awarding of townships to the Government for the purpose of reserving areas of land for the construction of railroads and other public works, have been received with the utmost satisfaction by the people of the North-West Territories. We therefore respectfully urge upon your Excellency the expediency of adopting such measures as will enable the Government to carry out the provisions of this clause with dispatch and efficiency. We further request your Excellency to give immediate consideration to the question of the establishment of a Board of Surveyors for the purpose of surveying the lands reserved for the construction of railroads and other public works.

FALL POETRY.

In autumn and the winds are high,
Dark clouds hang on the wintry sky;
The cold blast sweeps over the bleak,
Old harsh winter is coming fast.

He shrinks, for he had not thought
An old coat for himself thought,
And now his feet are sore and bitter,
His toes hang at the door.

THOMAS O. DAVIS.

CHI-CHAT LOCALS

Gathered for a chat.

On Sunday morning last, the Rev. Thomas Macdonald, Bishop of Battleford, was ordained to the order of the priesthood by the Lord Bishop of the Saskatchewan, who was represented by his Lordship.

Revocation Notice.

We have been informed that a meeting will be held on Friday evening next, the 19th inst., in Mr. Foster's hall at 7.30 o'clock, of those who desire to assist in the undertaking referred to under the heading as suggested in our last issue. It is to be hoped that this will be a large and enthusiastic gathering of interested men and that our citizens generally will lend a helping hand so as to enable us an undertaking.

New Church Building.

Mr. James Treloar's new three storey building is now completed and forms one of the most striking features of the town. The ground floor is used as a spacious room, 35 feet by 56 is occupied by Messrs. W. & J. Smith, who have just started business. Mr. Elwood Johnson occupies a portion of the second floor, for his law offices, while Mr. J. C. Currie, French teacher, has his classes there.

The Surveyor.

Mr. J. H. Land, B.S., is still employed across the river with a large party laying off the land into townships and sections, but for what purpose we do not know. We have also heard that they have been made elsewhere by the authorities in Ottawa that they could not find any surveyors willing to undertake the work. We understand that Mr. Land will through his present contract, in about three months, be obliged to take further contracts, and would undertake to lay out thirty townships before April 1st, or he would have no excuse for delay.

The Telegraph.

The Telegraph poles are now being erected across the whole town, and the contractor has finished his work. We are greatly surprised that there will be no delay in the erection of the wires, enabling us to connect the telegraph, bringing the news and supplying the town for weeks. The company has been very generous for the work and advantages will be taken of it at once. We do not know whether Mr. Gibb, the telegrapher, will be able to get the new wires strung through the streets. It would be too late to install them now, as there is connection with the outside world, if we were left out in the cold for another winter. We trust that the company will be able to get the wires strung before the snow falls, and thus save considerable inconvenience.

Question of Education.

In connection with the question of education, we are anxious to see that the bishop's scheme by the Bishop for the diocese was carried out. We understand that the funds obtained from private sources are all to be applied to the Bishop's Fund, the College Fund, and the Cathedral Fund according as the Bishop may think best for the present state of the work. The amount of the Bishop's Fund is stated to be approximately only about one hundred pounds sterling for Catholic or Diocesan Church purposes. We understand that the Bishop's Christian knowledge has voted £200 sterling towards the cathedral or diocese and church on condition that the £200 sterling is paid from our own funds. The cathedral question is postponed until this summer.

Miss Mack & Co.

We would suggest to the clergyman of the different churches in Prince Albert the propriety of holding a joint prayer meeting throughout the town. They have been established for many of the principal heads of the religious denominations, and we think that such a meeting would be a great help to the religious life of the town. Independent of the religious question, it is in the public interest that the religious life of the town should be strengthened after (although, as journalists, we of course feel it was but their duty to look after the religious life of the town). If such a meeting were held, the members of the various churches would be encouraged to attend, and the religious life of the town would be strengthened.

COMMUNICATIONS.

Our Member,

To the Editor of the Times:

Sir,—According to the old saw "speech is silver but silence is gold," I desire to make a few remarks in this connection.

The meeting of the District of Albert, convened by Mr. Mackay, President of the North West Council, was attended by a thorough believer in the latter part of this proceeding. I have never been able fully to agree with any part of this proceeding. The Council has not seen fit to take any part in these proceedings which have been taken. There are two purposes involved in this organisation, the redress of grievances, and he appears to have been absent when this vote was taken. I am, therefore, satisfied with his conduct.

For these reasons, I do not propose to say anything further on this question.

I am, Sir, yours respectfully, etc.,

PRINCE ALBERT

THE MASS MEETING.

The public meeting of the inhabitants of Prince Albert and vicinity, which was held last week, was attended by a large number of the prominent citizens of the town. Mr. W. J. Murray was appointed chairman of the meeting, and Mr. Fitzkearside, secretary. Mr. Murray officially stated that the object of the meeting was to secure for Prince Albert the status of a incorporated town, the redress of grievances, and the right to vote.

The following resolutions were proposed at this meeting:—

WHEREAS the inhabitants of Prince Albert have been unable to secure the support of the Government in respect to the affairs of the town, and whereas it has been suggested that Prince Albert is unfit for incorporation, be it resolved that a delegation be sent to the Northwest Territories to secure the passage of legislation as above mentioned.

And whereas, there is no question whatever whether Prince Albert will ever be incorporated, and whereas it is evident that the people of Prince Albert will never be able to secure the passage of such legislation, be it resolved that the people of Prince Albert are hereby united in their refusal to submit to the rule of any foreign power.

Therefore resolved—That we, the delegates, who meet here today, do declare that we are determined to resist any attempt to incorporate us under any form of government except that which we have heretofore enjoyed.

AND WHEREAS, we have been informed that Prince Albert has always been refused the right to vote in respect to the matters above mentioned, be it resolved that we hereby declare our intention to vote for the incorporation of Prince Albert.

RESOLVED—That we hereby declare our intention to vote for the incorporateation of Prince Albert.

RESOLVED—That we hereby declare our intention to vote for the incorporateation of Prince Albert.

PRINCE ALBERT

THAT FERRY CROSSING.

To the Editor of the Times:

Sir,—I am on my way to Prince Albert and the ferry crossing on the Assiniboine River is now useless as the boat which used to cross the river is no longer in use, and the ferry which was formerly used is now out of service. It is probable that the boat will be sold, and the ferry may also be sold, as it is now impossible to get any passengers or teams across at this point.

STANLEY

In reference to the foregoing letter, I have to thank you for your kind offer, but I must inform you that I have never been at Stanley's Crossing since its opening, nor have I heard that any changes have been made in connection therewith.

Mr. Stanley is certainly justified in his letter, but I must protest against the manner in which it is written. It is unfortunate that such letters should be written as they are, and it is to be hoped that the citizens of Prince Albert will take measures to prevent such letters from being written in the future.

STANLEY

ITHINK THIS.

To the Editor of the Times:

Sir,—I have but little faith left in human nature after reading your letter of the other day. You speak of a man named Mr. Stanley, and how he has been selling land at a great profit. I don't believe it, sir, and I can only say that if this is true, the man deserves all the trouble he has given me.
